segments.text: This is an interview with John Leslin by John Walbert on date May 9, 1994, in Rockport, Texas, concerning the Rural Development... What was it?
The Rural... What was the official title?
Well, the function is Rural Development.
The name of the organization is the National Area Development Institute.
The National Area Development Institute.
And...
In interesting and accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is this all right with you?
Yes, of course.
Okay, this is so future historians, students, or researchers can listen to it and are free to use any of the statements in this interview.
The thing we'd like to start out with is where did rural development start out?
Whose idea was it, and how did you get interested in it?
Oh, rural development goes back a long ways.
It started out, I've seen literature that goes back to the 1800s.
And when you think in terms of the canals that were put in and the roads that were put in.
So if you talk about rural, and rural is defined as non-metropolitan or non-urban, it's generally speaking areas that primary activity was either in extraction industries or in farming.
But when exactly did you get interested in joining any sort of organization or agency to help out rural communities?
I joined the Spinneltop Research Organization in Lexington, Kentucky, a non-profit research entity that was established by the Commonwealth of Kentucky to help in the development of Kentucky.
And that was in 63.
By 65, I was involved in
doing studies in Appalachian, Kentucky, to try to help identify opportunities for job creation and opportunities for getting communities to work together so that they could get something done.
We use the term scale, access, and scope.
You've got to have enough scale to do something, and you have to have enough scope, a range of activities in order for it to be cohesive.
And then you can't have everything, so you have to have access to what you need.
For example, in Appalachia, you have to have access to the outside world.
The road system was so poor that it was isolated.
They've been in highways, Appalachian development highways, and then they had access to the real world.
And whatever they did produce, they could get it to the markets.
But

Really, the National Area Development Institute was started about 1968 as a part of spin-on-top research by means of a grant from the Ford Foundation, which supported us for about five years, along with research contracts with half a dozen federal agencies.
How closely did you work with President Johnson's Great Society programs to bring Appalachia into the mainstream of American society?
I mean, he had read books about the other America, and he had tried with this Great Society program to bring in a lot of the persons who were below the poverty line.
How closely did you work with some of the governing agencies under President Johnson's administration?
Well, you remember the idea for helping Appalachia

occurred to john kennedy before his assassination by virtue of the stopover he made in west virginia and he saw the conditions there and he had no idea things were like that when johnson took over he had a commitment he made a commitment to enacting the legislation that would carry out the dream that john kennedy had
And so it was Kennedy's idea, Johnson put it into action.
In 1968, if I'm not mistaken, the Economic Development Administration was formed, the Appalachian Rural Development, the Appalachian Regional Development Program was started.
The Appalachian Regional Commission, excuse me, as a governing body composed of governors of the 13 Appalachian states became active.
And that's when I got very active in the Appalachian region.
My first study was in the four poorest counties in Appalachia, Lee, Wolf, Brethren, and Owsley counties.
And they were so isolated, they hadn't joined the 19th century, literally.
And it was a fascinating experience to meet and talk with these people, help them discover ways in which they could do things they'd never thought about doing before, as simple as
Hey, they could put a little bakery in town.
Instead of buying it from Louisville or Lexington, they could make it on and keep that money in the community.
One of the fellows suggested there were some caves out there and some old mines.
Maybe they could grow mushrooms.
And we looked into that for them, and some five years later, they have a major mushroom-producing activity in an old coal mine.
It uses manure from the horse farms in Lexington that is shipped in with the empty freight cars that carry the coal out.
See, that's how you get scale, scope, and access to bring about something.
And in order to get the scale, you have to, generally speaking, involve several political entities in order to have enough resources, money, and manpower, and political power.
to get anything accomplished.
So how did you find out a lot of this?

Was it mostly in the field interviews or working with probably any government entities in the local level in Kentucky, or pretty much y'all were just on your own going out and interviewing persons or interviewing farmers?
How did you find out a lot of this information?
Was it just in the field work mostly?
Well, let me start by saying that...

I had the good fortune to work with a man who was the brains that invented the notion of the Appalachian Regional Commission and structured it, and later became the representative of the Appalachian governors in Washington to administer the program.
His name was John Wissman.
And John introduced me to the lore of East Kentucky.
He was an East Kentucky boy himself, and the governor who put Spinnletop together was an East Kentucky product.
And so we had all the access that we needed.
And with regard to getting information, there was very little statistical information that you could go to and had any meaning to it because you didn't have it.
The culture was so different that it didn't really make sense.
But what we did was we talked to people.
We interviewed individuals.
We had collective meetings by counties.
I remember one in particular in Wolf County.
We called a meeting to help them, you know, what do you call it, brainstorm.
How can we create jobs out here?
And the people were all very polite, and finally this one big man, huge guy,
got up.
His name was Mr. Stovall, and he was the director of a private school, charity school out there.
He said, Mr. Leslie, we appreciate your interest in helping us talk about this sort of thing, but what we're here for is to find out do we plant tomatoes or not this year?
And I said, why?

And they had made applications for an EDA grant to use some of the wasted energy to have hothouses in which they could grow tomatoes, but they didn't have an adequate marketing structure, so it didn't get off the ground.
So you were continually blindsided by that kind of a situation.
We went to one county to see the county judge, and he'd been arrested and was in county jail for bootlegging.
So we went to the banker, and I had taken with me a young man who was a graduate student at the University of Kentucky who was raised in that area, and his
Uncle was a congressman, and the banker trusted him, and I would ask the banker a question.
He would look at Wibby Pratt, and Wibby Pratt would nod his head.
He'd turn around and answer the question.
If Wibby didn't nod his head, he wouldn't answer the question.
So this was a land of education for me, and nobody in those days knew anything really in a structured way that you could go out and teach rural development.
And so this gave me the opportunity to just have to start at ground zero with everybody else.
I had no academic background for this, because at that time, there was no academic training available.
So you just used common sense, put things together, and tried them out.
If it worked, you remembered it.
Ultimately, we put on some 13 national rural development leader schools under the auspices of the Rural Development Service of the Department of Agriculture across the nation.
about 100 leaders, rural leaders in each class, so that they could learn how to achieve the scale, scope, and access that is necessary to make something work.
Was there a particular position title that you held during this time, or was it pretty much you were the director of this whole geographic area, or how did that work?
Well, I'm talking Spindletop Research and NAIDI,
together because they were together initially.
Ultimately, NAIDI was spun off from Spindletop Research.
At Spindletop Research, by the time I left there, I was vice president of Spindletop Research and secretary of the National Area Development Institute.
When we split it off, I became president of the National Area Development Institute, headquartered in Lexington, Kentucky.
Ultimately, we moved it to Rockport, Texas, and it was a nonprofit organization.
It was not a member of any government or ties.
It did research work for, oh, golly, agencies in the federal government, USDA, Economic Development Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, Department of Transportation.
National Academy of Science, the Appalachian Regional Commission, the Department of Defense, Library of Congress, Congressional Research Service, Office of Economic Opportunity.
We did research projects for all of those federal agencies to help educate them that their request, and they paid for it, to come to grips with the rural thing.
Everybody knew about the urban mess, but they didn't

And really, that was the primary reason for establishing the Nice Marietta Institute with Ford Foundation support, because the Urban Institute was a mature organization, and the rural areas had no counterpart organization.
And so you weren't getting a balanced treatment.
How long did this work in Kentucky?
Is it still going on today?
Or pretty much, was there a time frame that most of this stayed on?
It varies all over the country.
Kentucky has gone through all sorts of gyrations.
John Wiseman lives in Kentucky, and he's consulted with all the governors since those days and is currently working with the governor.
The area development districts, multi-county organizations that were established in Kentucky are still existent and still active.

And incidentally, at NAIDAC, we did the initial development programs for each of those sub-state districts, area development districts, in conjunction with the people out in the field, through this interview, getting them involved.
Because the one thing you learn in real development, you can come in with the best idea in the world and ain't nobody going to buy it.
What you got to do is have them come up with it and have somebody emotionally committed to it, and then it will work.
Where else has this worked?
Have you worked with it in any area besides Kentucky or since then?
I was a consultant to the Rural Development Service at the Department of Agriculture for a number of years, hired through NAIDAC.
And that's where we conceived and put on these schools for the department.
And we covered the United States and Hawaii.
in the administration of Jimmy Carter, we promoted the use of state rural development committees in all fifty states.
I went around the country talking to governors and talking to people in the rural development business, showing them how this could work.
There was a series of goals that Carter had promulgated, and then we reported and pushed
pull to get that going.
When Carter left and Reagan came in, things slowed down.
Ultimately, in 1986, the Rural Development Service, or Office of Rural Development Policyit had several nameswas unfunded, and it all went out of existence.
I left there at that time.
By that time, I had joined the
Office of Rural Development Policy, a senior policy coordination officer.
And just, I retired.
What are some of the lasting ideas and projects that you came up with there?

I mean, was there any sort of thing where you'd gone into schools and tried to promote, instead of the focus going directly into preparing for college, were there any sort of vocational trainings for schools that the...
R-A-D-I had really looked into?

Well, early on, while it's been on top of research, I did a study that's been called seminal in developing the curriculum for a post-high school vocational program, two-year program, in central Kentucky for 17 counties.
And that school is still going.
It took them about 10 years to get it implemented.
And the reason for that was
They didn't have the teachers who knew how to teach what needed to be taught, and you couldn't just fire the ones who were teaching what they were teaching.
You had to wait until they retired, so you couldn't do it.
Oh, I think one of the most memorable things is I worked with a joint executive branchchaired, as a matter of factcommittee, executive branch, House of Representatives, and the Senate
rewrite the Rural Development Act of 1972, get rid of five onerous reports that nobody wanted, didn't read, and the paper wasn't anything too good for an outhouse even.
It was a significant event, and it was a lot of fun working on that.
What are some of the lasting results that you see?

school there, but what are the other big results that you really, when you look back at it, you can say, hey, that was great to be a part of, and boy, that was neat that that's happened, and it really made a difference.
What is probably the biggest three things you're most proud of?
Well, you know, rural development is small scale, so there are never any major things.
I felt good about seeing that mushroom production facility go in.
The Appalachian Highway system

which we developed a new technique for locating the route of the Appalachian highway system on the basis of what were the developmental opportunities rather than what's the cheapest and shortest distance, because the object was to open it up and make it productive.
Highway engineers just don't think that way.
We were successful in routing all the major highways through Appalachia
for maximum developmental potential.
And it turned central Appalachia around, and it is better off today significantly than it was in the 60s and 70s.
So those are typical.
And I felt good about these National Rural Development Leaders Schools.
It changed people's lives.
They would come in and say, boy, that was an experience, and I've changed my occupation.
I'm involved in this community development stuff, and it all goes back to taking that course.
This was a five-day course, ten to twelve hours a day.
We believed in marathon training and a combination of lectures and a work project using a case study approach.
So people got so involved, and they really did have that, aha, I see.
And that makes an educator feel good when they finally say, oh, that's what you're talking about.
That makes sense.
And what background were you able to draw upon this?
Where were you originally from and where was your education at?
Did it really apply to what you were doing there?
I got a degree in electrical engineering from the University of Texas in 1948, 47 or 48.
and went to work with the General Electric Company in the Knowles Atomic Power Laboratory.
It doesn't have much to do with rural development, but my assignment was in employee relations, management development, communications, training.
I developed a graduate education program in conjunction with RPI, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, leading to a master's degree in nuclear engineering.
which was a seminal event.
The schools were behind.
They had to learn from the industry what was going on.
And, you know, rural development is not complicated.
It's pretty simple, and it's common sense.
And once you see that you've got to get a lot of people together and find ways for them to get behind something, and there's no simple way to do it.
It's just

the learning that you got to give credit to get credit and you got to give credit to get action it can't be your idea it's got to be their idea and you learn a few of those simple things and the process you start out by finding out what are the assets of this area what do they got that they could might make some use of and what are the interests of people there and then when you
What are the opportunities to value add to agricultural products?
Don't just cut the beans down, can them and process them there.
When you catch the fish, process the fish.
And that has gone on all across the United States.
Small companies, now that we have transportation systems the way they are, Montana, for example, is a delightful place to live.
And many high-technical outfits are located in Montana because they like it.
And with Overnight Federal Express, they can compete with anybody.
Their living costs are less, and they're living in a lifestyle they want to live.
So rural areas offer a lot.
On the other hand, if you want the excitement of a major metropolitan area,

dodge bullets every night when you're coming home, while you can stay in these big cities and have your doors all locked up and live a scared-to-death life, which is not very appealing to some people.
In Texas, we've got an extensive farm-to-market road system for its agriculture products.

We've got a very active agriculture commissioner presently, Rick Perry, who's with the new North American Free Trade Agreement, is really pushing Texas agricultural products to Mexico since they are our biggest trading partner.
Now that you've retired and are now in Texas, do you see a lot of the goals that you looked at trying to implement in this 1960s in Kentucky, did you see these goals?
that you looked at, are they pretty much paralleled and been made here in Texas?
I've really not gotten close to what goes on in Texas, I'm ashamed to say.
It seems like it's always you're an expert when you get 200 miles away rather than when you're there.
And I get involved in the local community here.
I started a Good Samaritan organization for emergency assistance to the poor
and using the principles that we taught in rural development.
And the community just bought it.
It was their idea, and I just got them together and talked and wore them out until they decided to do something, and it worked.
So Texas' worst roads are better than most states' good roads when you get away from the interstate system.
But Texas has the finest road system in the world.
in my opinion.
It doesn't have access problems except for distance.
When you're trying to get to El Paso, I don't care how good the road is, it's a long ways.
Recent trends in agriculture that I've been seeing in Texas through being at Texas A&M

It's tending to go more towards genetically altered vegetables, and so you have a juicier, bigger tomato than, you know, we have the 10-15 onion and a lot of these real kind of fancy technological advances.
Did the University of Kentucky ever really present something like this to your research when y'all were working, to these small...
places in Appalachia, did they come in and say, hey, you know, we've got this idea and this new crop, and we want to really have a testing ground.
Do you all want to try this?

Well, most of that activity was done by the Extension Service, and that is quite dependent on the interest and the expertise of the Extension agent that is responsible for an area, and some of them have been very aggressive in
in promoting the latest ways to produce and process agricultural products.
By and large, the Rural Development Service, NAIDI, were concerned primarily with non-agricultural activities because the agriculture thing goes on its own pretty well.
It was the absence of
of economic activity that was killing them because the efficiency of agriculture production has gone up so high now that its employment base is very low.
And if you're looking for employment, you really have to look at processing or something like that, not genetic devices.
What you're going to find out there is it's going to cause less employment because it's easier to produce and you get a higher yield.
for the same amount of labor, and so you're market dependent.
You see what I mean?

I noticed looking at some of the great society agencies that started and some of the New Deal policies that continued on, there was the Rural Electric Council, which had provided electricity to rural Americans.
And a lot of places, at least in Texas, have formed electric cooperatives
to provide electricity to run some of the local rural businesses.

Was this a big factor in some of the Appalachian areas, trying to get some of the government or try to get the people to form an electric cooperative to get everyone power, or did pretty much everyone have it, or what were their thoughts on it?
The Real Electric Administration has been very active in real development since its inception.
And

The real problem that they face now is there are a lot of people who feel it's not fair that rural electrics can loan money at a lower rate and therefore, in a sense, be subsidized while other power companies can't.
Now, once the system was built, the maintenance problems aren't as expensive as they were when it was first put in.
My wife was raised out in west Texas on a ranch, and they didn't get electricity until the mid-50s.
Had it not been for REA, they still wouldn't have electricity.
It's impossible.
You just really can't quantify that in any isolated area, which west Texas is isolated by distance, and Appalachia by the wrinkled mountains and the terrain.
And so wherever there was a problem that made provision of electric current not economical going the private way, this is the only way they could do it.
But that need is really not as much as it is, and there's been a constant force in Congress to reduce the subsidy that goes in that direction.
You mentioned that you retired in 1986.
And what have you seen since then, since the organizations you work with that pretty much remain unfunded?
And what has the organization done since your retirement?
Or has it pretty much ceased to exist?
And has any other organization picked up the slack where you all left off?
Well, I retired, but that doesn't mean I've quit working.
I've been a consultant to the Future Farmers of America, where we developed for them several programs.
And the major program that we worked with them on was their community development program.
They had chapters from all over the United States compete for community development or area development or rural development, whatever you want to call it.
And they had some projects that you wouldn't believe that they got started in rural areas.
Traditionally, Future Farms of America has been just agricultural and stock shows and that sort of thing and agricultural products.

They brought it into the fold of something that they could get involved in the community with, and they ran tractor safety programs that we designed for them, a double line for safety for use of seat belts and not drinking while driving.
Programs were promulgated, all in the sense of community development in the future parts of America.
The National Association of State Development

agencies nasdaq they call it i've consulted with them most recently in montana helping the governor of montana put on town meetings in 11 cities in montana which was an exciting experience it was again just people to people getting their views finding where there was consensus seeing how to build on the consensus and move on from there it's rarely a
a big announcement that the world has suddenly got better.
It's a lot of little bitty things where things improve.
And you look back 10 years later and say, boy, I don't know whether you want to call it improved or not, but when we moved to Rockport in 1975, there was one traffic light in town.
Now we have 11.
You're going to vary as to whether the old timers don't think that's much improvement there.
But now we're going to bypass around the town.
we can get rid of our stoplights.
You mentioned with the safety and then the traffic lights, some of the results here, but what were the goals that you looked at?
Nate, what were the goals that you looked at?
I mean, all the other, the hard work really notwithstanding, what were the goals that you were working for?
What was the ideal result?
Basically, it was to make our rural areas a better place to work, live, play, and pray.
In other words, the quality of life is your goal.
Why should the rural people have a lousy quality of life?

And so I think the quality of life has improved considerably throughout the United States in rural areas, perhaps at a faster rate than in the cities, given their current propensity to crime and the underclass development and some almost intractable
problems.
Matter of fact, the thing that interested me the most and got me involved in rural development was we operated on a scale where you could make something happen and you could study the problem.
When you try to do the same thing in New York City, Washington, D.C., Boston, that's breaking it down to neighborhoods.
In rural areas, we put things together to build it up enough to have enough scale.
In metropolitan areas, they've got to break it down to get it
to enough scale that you can even fool with it.
And then there's so many interacting forces that you don't have in the rural setting.
So it's a lot tougher to solve those urban problems than it is the rural problems.
They have their problems, but I'll take those any day over the metropolitan area.
Well, I think that pretty much concludes the interview.
Is there anything else you'd like to leave future researchers, students, and listeners to this interview, leave them with about rural development?
Well, I guess if a guy with as little formal training as I had, and I didn't realize this at the time, but I just had a tremendous opportunity to learn.
And I learned from so many people.
I didn't learn how to do a regression analysis, but I never had to do one.
I had people that worked for me who could do a regression analysis.

so many things in life where you need the technical knowledge, but there are other things you need, some other kind of skills to put the technical knowledge to work, to get people to work together on it, so that two brains are better than one, maybe equivalent to three.
You know, you're not limited by the
zero-sums game in development.
You always increase the size of the pie rather than define how you divide it, which traditional economic models apply.
I don't know whether you remember Leon Tiff or not, the guy who invented input-output models.
Well, I participated on a panel he chaired in the Senate for a hearing, and everybody up there except me had Ph.D.s in economics.
But I raised questions.
If the data is no good, you can model all you want to, and we have a data problem.
I made a talk once to the National Society.
I can't remember the name of it.
These systems people reported that the 1970 census showed that 72 people
commuted daily to Hawaii from Los Angeles by automobile.
How do you do that?
Data error.
Displace concreteness.
When you see numbers on a page, it gives them some validity.
It's a rare person who likes to deal
with getting the data, because then they're aware of the soft spots in the data.
But if they take somebody else's data, well, that's fine.
Those are hard numbers.
Two is two and three is three.
So, you know, it's a tough one.
But anyway, this Lintef guy was quite interesting, and he spent more time talking to me than he did to any of the people after it was over.
Because he said, I don't ever get the people who are as close to the problem as you are.
You know, we in the ivory towers just don't have the opportunity to get their hands on it and trying to quantify things.
So I think that was an insight worth having.
Thank you, Mr. Leslie.
Well, thank you, John.
Good luck to you.
